titleText.ttltext: Less Common Gynecologic Malignancies: An Integrative Review

abstracts.publisherCopyright: Copyright © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
paras: OBJECTIVE: To review current data on vaginal, vulvar, and fallopian tube cancers, including incidence, diagnosis, staging, risk reduction measures, and management. DATA SOURCES: A review of retrieved articles dated 2006-2018 from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end. CONCLUSION: Early diagnosis and treatment of rare gynecologic cancers is dependent on a thorough history and examination. Of particular interest is the role of fallopian tube as the location of primary origin of ovarian and peritoneal cancers as well as the potential for @hit_startvaccination@hit_end prevention of vaginal and vulvar cancers. IMPLICATIONS FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Nurses in diverse roles should have an understanding of these rare tumor types to support assessment and early identification with their patients.

titleText.ttltext: Cervical Cancer: An Overview of Pathophysiology and Management

abstracts.publisherCopyright: Copyright © 2019 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
paras: OBJECTIVE: To provide an overview of the etiology, prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and long-term survivorship concerns surrounding cervical cancer. DATA SOURCES: A review of articles dated 2006-2018 from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end. CONCLUSION: The landscape for cervical cancer is changing dramatically because of @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-driven@hit_end prevention. Despite these advances, there are both newly diagnosed individuals as well as survivors of cervical cancer who require continued evidence-based care. IMPLICATION FOR NURSING PRACTICE: Nurses are integral in diverse settings to promote prevention through timely @hit_startvaccination@hit_end, as well as to educate patients about the signs, symptoms, and management of cervical cancer when it occurs.

titleText.ttltext: Human Papillomavirus @hit_startVaccination@hit_end and Anogenital Warts: A @hit_startSystematic Review@hit_end of Impact and Effectiveness in the United States

organizations: Department of Epidemiology of Microbial Diseases, Yale School of Public Health

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 American Sexually Transmitted Diseases Association All rights reserved.
paras: Background Assessing the impact and effectiveness of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end on anogenital warts in the United States can provide early indication of the success of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end programs as well as identify potential areas for improvement. Methods Articles were identified from the @hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startMedline@hit_end, and @hit_startEmbase@hit_end databases. Exclusion criteria were applied, and remaining studies were then classified as impact or effectiveness studies. Results Eight eligible studies published through March 2018 were included. Population-based impact studies examining trends in diagnoses reported consistent declines in females ages 25 years and younger after 2006 when routine female @hit_startvaccination@hit_end began in the United States. Declines in males ages 25 years and younger were also seen; however, these declines were lower than those in females and more evident after routine male @hit_startvaccination@hit_end began in 2011. Among females and males older than 25 years, little to no change has been seen in the trends of anogenital warts since 2006. Studies that included the pre-@hit_startvaccine@hit_end era (before 2006) reported increasing trends during this period. After @hit_startvaccine@hit_end introduction, a reversal in these trends was observed. Effectiveness studies that included individual-level @hit_startvaccination@hit_end histories consistently demonstrated a lower risk of anogenital warts for those receiving at least one dose of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end compared to those unvaccinated. Conclusions These findings suggest that the degree of HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end impact has varied substantially by age and sex. Achieving the full prevention potential of HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end will likely require greater coverage among both females and males. Post-licensure estimates of effectiveness demonstrate the real-world benefit of the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end.

organizations: HPV Research Group, Barretos Cancer Hospital

paras: HPV is the most common sexually transmitted biological agent and is the cause of many conditions in men and women, including precancer lesions and cancer. Three prophylactic HPV @hit_startvaccines@hit_end targeting high-risk HPV types are available in many countries worldwide: 2-, 4- and 9-valent @hit_startvaccines@hit_end. All the 3 @hit_startvaccines@hit_end use recombinant DNA technology and are prepared from the purified L1 protein that self-assembles to form HPV type-specific empty shells. This non-@hit_startsystematic review@hit_end aims to summarize the HPV epidemiology and the @hit_startvaccine@hit_end development to review the landmark trials of HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end, to present to most remarkable results from clinical trials and the real world, and to stress the challenges and the barriers for HPV @hit_startvaccine@hit_end implementation.

titleText.ttltext: Blood donation barriers and facilitators of Sub-Saharan African migrants and minorities in Western high-income countries: a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end of the @hit_startliterature@hit_end

organizations: Department of Donor Studies, Sanquin Research

abstracts.publisherCopyright: © 2018 The Authors. Transfusion Medicine published by John Wiley & Sons Ltd on behalf of British Blood Transfusion Society
paras: Objectives: The present study aimed to gain more insight into, and summarise, blood donation determinants among migrants or minorities of Sub-Saharan heritage by @hit_startsystematically reviewing@hit_end the current @hit_startliterature@hit_end. Background: Sub-Saharan Africans are under-represented in the blood donor population in Western high-income countries. This causes a lack of specific blood types for transfusions and prevention of alloimmunisation among Sub-Saharan African patients. Methods/materials: @hit_startMedline@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, @hit_startPsycINFO@hit_end and BIOSIS were searched for relevant empirical studies that focused on barriers and facilitators of blood donation among Sub-Saharan Africans in Western countries until 22 June 2017. Of the 679 articles screened by title and abstract, 152 were subsequently screened by full text. Paired reviewers independently assessed the studies based on predefined eligibility and quality criteria. Results: Of the 31 included studies, 24 used quantitative and 7 used qualitative research methods. Target cohorts varied from Black African Americans and refugees from Sub-Sahara Africa to specific Sub-Saharan migrant groups such as Comorians or Ethiopians. Main recurring barriers for Sub-Saharan Africans were haemoglobin deferral, fear of needles and pain, social exclusion, lack of awareness, negative attitudes and accessibility problems. Important recurring facilitators for Sub-Saharan Africans were altruism, free health checks and specific recruitment and awareness-raising campaigns. Conclusion: The findings of this review can be used as a starting point to develop recruitment and retention strategies for Sub-Saharan African persons. Further research is needed to gain more insight in the role of these determinants in specific contexts as socioeconomic features, personal histories and host country regulations may differ per country.

titleText.ttltext: Bats, rabies and a skilled nursing facility: A potentially lethal combination

paras: Background: Over the past several decades long term care (LTC) facilities have developed infection control practices to prevent disease outbreaks. These include hand hygiene, isolation, immunizations, and indwelling catheter care. When standard guidelines are not avail-able for LTC settings, community standards are often applied. In our skilled nursing facility (SNF), a bat was found perched on the ceiling of a recreational room. After @hit_startreview@hit_end of the @hit_startliterature@hit_end, no reports were found detailing an infection control guideline for potential bat expo-sure in an LTC facility. Given the lack of such guidelines, this report aims to describe a standardized protocol for exposure to bats in an LTC facility. Methods: To determine the bat's point of entry and whether residents or staff were exposed, security footage was reviewed. Pest control staff, who captured the bat, were interviewed. A system-atic @hit_startliterature review@hit_end was conducted using the following databases: @hit_startPubMED@hit_end, @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end, @hit_startCochrane@hit_end library and web-based search engines. Keywords included "bats," "post acute," "skilled nursing facility," and "assisted living," amongst others. A comprehensive list is included in Appendix A. Results: First contact with the bat was made by pest control who captured the bat. Security footage confirmed that the bat entered the SNF through the garage and flew into an unoccupied recreational room. It did not enter any occupied spaces or patient care areas. An infectious disease specialist was consulted and LTC leadership even-tually concluded that no residents or staff were bitten or exposed to bodily fluid and the bat was subsequently released without any testing. Conclusion: In the absence of relevant LTC @hit_startliterature@hit_end, we @hit_startreviewed@hit_end guidelines for bat exposure in the community. In the absence of security footage detailing the bat's path, the degree of exposure to LTC residents would have been unclear. In a densely occupied LTC facility with cognitively impaired patients, we would have to assume widespread exposure and perform mass post exposure prophylaxis, including a series of rabies @hit_startvaccine@hit_end and immunoglobulin. Testing of the bat would also be mandatory. The aim of this report is to iden-tify the challenges of potential rabies exposure in LTC facilities and describe a standardized protocol.

titleText.ttltext: Efficacy and safety of the pneumococcal conjugate-13 valent @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in adults

organizations: Faculty of Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of British Columbia

paras: Invasive pneumococcal disease and pneumococcal pneumonia cause substantial morbidity and mortality in the elderly. This review focuses on the immunogenicity, safety, efficacy and effectiveness data on the use of the 13-valent conjugate pneumococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PCV13) in adults. A @hit_startMEDLINE@hit_end literature search was performed from January 1946 to December 2017. Additional references were identified from a @hit_startreview@hit_end of @hit_startliterature@hit_end citations. All English-language randomized trials, observational studies and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analyses@hit_end assessing the immunogenicity, efficacy, effectiveness and safety of PCV13 in adults were evaluated. Six randomized controlled studies evaluated immunogenicity and safety of PCV13 in adults and showed that the conjugated @hit_startvaccine@hit_end elicited a greater immune response to the majority of the 13 serotypes compared to the 23-valent polysaccharide pneumococcal @hit_startvaccine@hit_end (PPV23). Administering PCV13 prior to PPV23 elicits greater immune responses and multiple doses of PCV13 demonstrated modest advantage. PCV13 titers declined after a year but remained above baseline. A randomized clinical trial (CAPiTA) showed that PCV13 was effective in preventing community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and @hit_startvaccine@hit_end@hit_start-type@hit_end invasive pneumococcal disease, but not any cause pneumonia. Safety data shows PCV13 elicits minor local reactions, such as pain at the injection site. Major side effects that were commonly reported included muscle fatigue and headache. Both local and systemic adverse events were comparable to PPV23. While PCV13 has a well-established immunogenicity and safety profile in adults, there is sparse data on sequential or multiple dosing, efficacy and effectiveness in adults. As there are few countries who have adopted PCV13 for routine adult @hit_startimmunization@hit_end, there is a need to evaluate the effectiveness of PCV13 in a real-world setting.

titleText.ttltext: @hit_startSystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end of cost-effectiveness of rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in low-income and lower-middle-income countries

organizations: Social Administrative Pharmacy Excellence Research (SAPER) Unit, Department of Pharmacy, Mahidol University

paras: Background. Rotavirus causes morbidity and mortality in children particularly in low-income countries (LICs) and lowermiddle- income countries (LMICs). This @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end aimed to assess cost-effectiveness of rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in LICs and LMICs. Methods. Relevant studies were identified from @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and Scopus from their inception to January 2019. Studies were eligible if they assessed the cost-effectiveness of rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end in children in LICs and LMICs and reported incremental cost-effectiveness ratios. Risk of bias and quality assessment was assessed based on the Consolidated Health Economic Evaluation Reporting Standard checklist. Incremental net benefits (INBs) were estimated, and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end based on the DerSimonian and Laird method was applied to pool INBs across studies. Results. We identified 1614 studies, of which 28 studies (29 countries) were eligible and conducted using cost-utility @hit_startanalysis@hit_end in LICs (n = 8) and LMICs (n = 21). The pooled INB was estimated at $62.17 (95% confidence interval, $7.12-$117.21) in LICs, with a highly significant heterogeneity (χ@sup_begin2@sup_end = 33.96; df = 6; P < .001; I2 = 82.3%), whereas the pooled INB in LMICs was $82.46 (95% confidence interval, $54.52-$110.41) with no heterogeneity (χ@sup_begin2@sup_end = 8.46; df = 11; P = .67; I2 = 0%). Conclusions. Rotavirus @hit_startvaccine@hit_end would be cost-effective to introduce in LICs and LMICs. These findings could aid decision makers and provide evidence for introduction of rotavirus @hit_startvaccination@hit_end.

titleText.ttltext: The effect of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end on mortality and risk of hospitalization in patients with heart failure: A @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Warren Alpert Medical School, Brown University, Rhode Island Hospital

paras: Background. Influenza is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in patients diagnosed with heart failure. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effectiveness of influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end in this population in terms of reduction in all-cause mortality and rate of hospitalization. Methods. We conducted a @hit_startsystematic review@hit_end and @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end using @hit_startPubMed@hit_end and @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end entries from January of 2000 through April 2018. Publication bias was examined using the Egger's regression test. Statistical heterogeneity was examined using the Higgins I2 statistic. Subgroup @hit_startanalyses@hit_end were performed to examine the effect of @hit_startvaccination@hit_end during the influenza and noninfluenza seasons. Results. We identified 8 studies that included a total of 82 354 patients with heart failure. In patients with heart failure who were @hit_startvaccinated@hit_end against influenza, we found a reduced risk of all-cause mortality (hazard ratio [HR], 0.69; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.51-0.87). No evidence of publication bias was found, and the effect was more pronounced during influenza season (HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.30-0.69), compared with noninfluenza season (HR, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.68-0.89). In terms of heart failure hospitalizations, we did not identify a statistically significant difference between the cohorts (HR, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.00-1.23). Conclusions. Influenza @hit_startvaccination@hit_end was associated with a decreased risk of all-cause mortality in patients with heart failure, and this effect was more prominent during the influenza season.

titleText.ttltext: Streptococcus agalactiae maternal colonization, antibiotic resistance and serotype profiles in Africa: A @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end

organizations: Department of Medical Microbiology, School of Biomedical and Laboratory Sciences, College of Medicine and Health Sciences, University of Gondar

paras: Background: Maternal rectovaginal colonization with Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus or GBS) is the most common route for the GBS disease in the perinatal period. The knowledge of maternal colonization, antibiotic resistance and serotype profiles is substantially needed to formulate the broad @hit_startvaccine@hit_end. However, it has not been estimated in Africa. This @hit_startmeta@hit_end@hit_start-analysis@hit_end was aimed to determine the pooled prevalence of colonization, antibiotic resistance and serotype profiles of GBS reported in Africa. Methods: Potentially relevant studies from 1989 to 31th January, 2019 were retrieved from the @hit_startMedline@hit_end/@hit_startPubMed@hit_end, @hit_startEMBASE@hit_end, HINARI online databases, periodicals and by requesting authors. Unpublished studies retrieved from grey literature through Google and Google Scholar. Pooled estimates were calculated using the random effect model. Subgroup @hit_startanalysis@hit_end was done to investigate the burden of colonization across sub-regions, sampling site and countries. Summary estimates were presented using words, Forest plots and Tables. Heterogeneity was assessed using the I@sup_begin2@sup_end statistic. Results: Eighty-three articles were assessed, of which 57 studies conducted in five sub-regions with 21 countries (22,206 pregnant women) met pre-specified inclusion criteria. The overall estimate of recto-vaginal colonization was 19.3% (95% CI 16.9, 21.7). The highest estimate was observed in Southern Africa, 23.8% (95% CI 18.7, 28.9), followed by Northern Africa, 22.7% (95% CI 18.2, 27.2) while the lowest was driven from the Eastern Africa, 15.4% (95% CI 12.1, 18.7). Considerable heterogeneity across and within regions, sampling site, screening methods and countries (I@sup_begin2@sup_end > 75%); and the publication bias were observed (p = 0.031). GBS showed the highest resistance to tetracycline. Resistance to penicillin, amoxicillin, chloramphenicol, ampicillin, ceftriaxone, ciprofloxacin, erythromycin, vancomycin and clindamycin also observed. The V, III, Ia, Ib, and II serotypes altogether were accounted 91.8% in the African studies. Conclusions: The pooled estimate of the maternal colonization with GBS was 19.3% which is equivalent with other many primary and review reports worldwide. The most antibiotic resistance estimate was recorded in the tetracycline followed by penicillin. Five serotypes were the most prevalent in Africa and more data on the antibiotic résistance and serotype distribution patterns are needed from developing countries to devise the effective preventive measures. In addition, the antibiotic susceptibility test methods used in the Africa shall be assessed for its quality. Trial registration Prospero Registration Number CRD42018094525

sourceTitle: Annals of Clinical Microbiology and Antimicrobials
